newsitem.title: USA: Crude oil, gas prices rise on Iraq missile firings.
newsitem.headline: Crude oil, gas prices rise on Iraq missile firings.

text.p: Crude oil prices rose sharply for a second consecutive session Wednesday after Iraq fired missiles at U.S. warplanes, reviving fears that supplies will be curtailed.

Cotton prices rose the maximum 3-cents-per-pound daily limit after the Agriculture Department released a surprisingly low U.S. crop estimate. Wheat prices tumbled after the department forecast a large U.S. crop.
The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 17 commodities was down 0.92 at 247.22.

Iraq's launching of the missiles and news the United States ordered stealth fighters and B-52 bombers to the Gulf region indicated Mideast tensions may be escalating, which could jeopardise the flow of oil from that region.
"The market is worried that the tension in Iraq could escalate even more every time the U.S. flies over the no-fly zone," said Ed Kevelson, director of refined products at Paribas Futures Inc.
At the New York Mercantile Exchange, October crude oil closed up 63 cents at $24.75 a barrel, after setting a contract high of $24.98 earlier.
October gasoline closed up 1.06 cents at 65.91 cents a gallon, and October heating oil rose 1.52 cents to 68.19 cents a gallon.

Traders bid cotton futures up the 3-cent daily limit at the New York Cotton Exchange after the Agriculture Department slashed nearly 700,000 bales from its previous U.S. crop estimate. NYCE October cotton closed up 3 cents at 74.90 cents per pound.

The Agriculture Department estimated this year's U.S. cotton crop at 17.900 million 480-pound bales, down from its August estimate of 18.577 million bales. The smaller estimate surprised analysts, especially those who expected a 100,000- to 200,000-bale increase from August.
"We are surprised by the big decrease in three key states," said Sharon Johnson, analyst with Frank Schneider & Co. "It was very much in conflict with what we were hearing in yields."
In a summary accompanying the crop estimate, the department attributed the decline to harmful hot weather in California and dry conditions in Arkansas and Louisana.
Some analysts said the high prices will curb demand for cotton, especially exports.
Bearish Agriculture Department wheat production forecasts for the United States and other countries hit wheat futures prices at the three major U.S. futures exchanges.
"The world has more wheat than anybody originally thought and the buyers' appetites aren't that big," said Skip Searcy, wheat trading specialist for FIMAT Futures USA Inc.
The department estimated this year's U.S. wheat crop at nearly 2.30 billion bushels, up from its August estimate of 2.25 billion.
It also increased its estimates for Australian and Canadian wheat crops.
"Canada will under cut us, Australia will undersell us and the EU is cranking up their subsidies," Searcy said.

The Chicago Board of Trade's December soft red winter wheat contract fell 15-1/4 cents to $4.37-1/2. Kansas City Board of Trade December hard red winter wheat closed down 15-1/4 at $4.36-3/4 and Minneapolis Grain Exchange December spring wheat was down 14 cents at $4.20.
